abstract: The government tried repeatedly for more than a year and a half to get the former president to give back documents from his time in office. Finally, it resorted to a search of his property.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government tried and failed repeatedly for more than a year and a half to retrieve classified and sensitive documents from former President Donald J. Trump before resorting to a search of his Mar-a-Lago property this month, according to government documents and statements by Mr. Trump’s lawyers.
headline: Inside the 20-Month Drive to Get Trump to Return Presidential Material
keywords: Trump, Donald J;Classified Information and State Secrets;Mar-a-Lago (Palm Beach, Fla);Archives and Records;National Archives and Records Administration;Search and Seizure;Federal Bureau of Investigation;Justice Department;United States Politics and Government

abstract: “She still warms me up,” Holt said of his mother, who won the U.S. Open twice. “She won’t miss one ball I hit back. Literally, not one. And if she does, she gets so mad.”
lead_paragraph: Tracy Austin put her hands to her head, then buried her face in them and, finally, raised two fists to the sky with a triumphant smile. It was not quite as exuberant as her celebration when she won the U.S. Open for the first time in 1979. But it was pretty close.
headline: Brandon Holt, Tracy Austin’s Son, Wins a Spot in U.S. Open Main Draw
keywords: Tennis;Content Type: Personal Profile;United States Open (Tennis);Austin, Tracy;Holt, Brandon (1998- )

abstract: Unredacted portions of the affidavit underlying the Mar-a-Lago search warrant point to a crime that has been overshadowed amid disputes over classified information.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Justice Department proposed redactions to the affidavit underlying the warrant used to search former President Donald J. Trump’s residence, prosecutors made clear that they feared the former president and his allies might take any opportunity to intimidate witnesses or otherwise illegally obstruct their investigation.
headline: Possibility of Obstruction Looms Over Trump After Thwarted Efforts to Recover Documents
keywords: Trump, Donald J;Classified Information and State Secrets;Espionage and Intelligence Services;Mar-a-Lago (Palm Beach, Fla);Archives and Records;National Archives and Records Administration;Federal Bureau of Investigation;Justice Department;Search and Seizure;United States Politics and Government

abstract: Andrew Linzer’s Saturday debut will have you searching for connections.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — What a tricky quintet of loosely conjoined little themeless grids we get today! I flew through the northeast corner, sprinkled in a couple of entries at the bottom and on the west side, and then just … stopped. I couldn’t rustle up a thing in the center and top of this puzzle for a long time, until I recalibrated my solving sensibilities to Andrew Linzer’s excellent, humorous wordplay.
headline: Confirmation, e.g.
keywords: Crossword Puzzles

abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 27, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about California’s plan to ban the sale of gasoline-powered cars featured a quotation that misstated the distinction of the California measure. While California is the first U.S. state government to mandate zero-emission vehicles, it is not the only government to have done so. (British Columbia has similar rules in place.)
headline: Corrections: Aug. 27, 2022

abstract: Since January, the 18-time Grand Slam champion has balanced her work in tennis with the grueling routine of chemotherapy for ovarian cancer. She never would have caught it early, if she hadn’t lost her sister to the same disease.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — All the medical advancements that helped save Chris Evert’s life could not save her sister. Jeanne Evert Dubin died of ovarian cancer in February 2020, at age 62, her illness discovered only after it had reached its deadliest stages.
headline: Chris Evert Needs Everyone to Listen
keywords: Tennis;Evert, Chris;Content Type: Personal Profile;Evert Dubin, Jeanne (1957-2020);United States Open (Tennis);Ovarian Cancer;Breast Cancer

abstract: Most New Yorkers give notice at their old apartments without a new one lined up. But that’s OK.
lead_paragraph: Q: I am moving from Connecticut to Manhattan later this year, and I’m concerned about how to time the move. My current landlord requires 60 days’ notice to move out. But from what I have seen, most apartments in New York are not listed until 30 days before they become available, and are rented even faster than that. I’m also considering renting in a co-op or condo, and those approval processes seem long. How do I time this right so I don’t end up paying for two apartments at once, or worse, giving up my apartment without a place to live?
headline: How Do I Time a Move From One Rental Apartment to Another?
keywords: Real Estate and Housing (Residential);Renting and Leasing (Real Estate);Landlords;Cooperatives;Condominiums

abstract: For better or worse, Jay Gould revolutionized the world of finance in the 19th century. In “American Rascal,” Greg Steinmetz tells his story.
lead_paragraph: On April 5, 1882, Theodore Roosevelt stood in the New York State Assembly and demanded an investigation. The indignant 23-year-old accused a clique of “swindlers,” “wealthy stock gamblers,” “men whose financial dishonesty is a matter of common notoriety,” of corruptly monopolizing New York City’s elevated railroads. The plot’s mastermind, he implied, was Jay Gould.
headline: The Robber Baron Who Remade Wall Street in His Own Image
keywords: Books and Literature;Content Type: Personal Profile;Corporations;Railroads;Stocks and Bonds;Banking and Financial Institutions;American Rascal: How Jay Gould Built Wall Street's Biggest Fortune (Book);Steinmetz, Gregory W (1961- );Gould, Jay (1836-92);Union Pacific Corporation;Western Union Company;United States

abstract: The city requires its pool lifeguards to meet standards similar to those set for ocean lifeguards, beyond what the state sets.
lead_paragraph: As temperatures climbed into the high 80s on a sunny afternoon this week, dozens of people trying to cool off at the public pool in McCarren Park in Williamsburg had only half the usual space, as the other side sat empty, blocked by traffic cones and caution tape.

abstract: As cephalopods become more important in neuroscience and other fields, scientists and welfare advocates seek to give the smart animals the same protections as mice and monkeys.
lead_paragraph: Lab rats have rights. Before researchers in the United States can experiment on the animals, they need approval from committees that ensure they follow federal regulations for housing and handling the creatures humanely. The same is true of scientists working with mice, monkeys, fish or finches.
headline: Octopuses Don’t Have Backbones — or Rights
keywords: Octopus;Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare;Animal Cognition;Research;Regulation and Deregulation of Industry;your-feed-science;your-feed-animals

abstract: The corporations that control these broadcasts know: It can still be hugely lucrative to provide an experience that fans come to despise.
lead_paragraph: It is, let’s say, 8:43 p.m. on a Saturday. You are watching a college football game that is taking place at this hour despite being played in the Midwest in November, and the people in the stadium, which is not entirely full, look very cold and a little put off. The season schedule said kickoff was at 8 p.m., but it didn’t actually take place until 8:18. In the 25 minutes that have elapsed, play has been interrupted for three commercial breaks. Each advertisement shown during these breaks has been for pickup trucks.
headline: Does Watching College Football on TV Have to Be So Miserable?
keywords: Football (College);Television;Advertising and Marketing;ESPN;Walt Disney Company;Fans (Persons)

abstract: San Franciscans are done apologizing for their cold Julys and Augusts. In a time of punishing heat waves, the city likes being a place to chill out.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — While Americans from Seattle to Memphis to New York sweated their way through the swampy summer of 2022, here was the scene on an August afternoon at Fisherman’s Wharf, on the northern tip of San Francisco: Among a group of friends from Germany gawking at dozens of barking sea lions splayed on floating docks, one was bundled in a down jacket and another in a sweatshirt, and a third was shivering despite a red checkered scarf worn like a shawl.
headline: Come for the Golden Gate Bridge and Cable Cars. Stay for the Summer Shivers.
keywords: San Francisco (Calif);Weather;Summer (Season);Travel and Vacations;Heat and Heat Waves;Global Warming;Wind

abstract: Increasingly, anxious and depressed teens are using multiple, powerful psychiatric drugs, many of them untested in adolescents or for use in tandem.

abstract: Is it really so inconceivable that one of the most famous people in the world could be trapped in the same closet as you or me?

abstract: The judge, an appointee of President Donald J. Trump, indicated she was prepared to grant Mr. Trump’s request for an arbiter, or special master, to review the documents seized by the F.B.I.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Florida gave notice on Saturday of her “preliminary intent” to appoint an independent arbiter, known as a special master, to conduct a review of the highly sensitive documents that were seized by the F.B.I. this month during a search of Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trump’s club and residence in Palm Beach.
headline: Judge Signals Intent to Appoint Special Master in Mar-a-Lago Search
keywords: Trump, Donald J;Classified Information and State Secrets;Mar-a-Lago (Palm Beach, Fla);Search and Seizure;Federal Bureau of Investigation;Justice Department;Executive Privilege, Doctrine of;United States Politics and Government;Cannon, Aileen M

abstract: The team said it had released the rookie punter Araiza after he was accused of raping a 17-year-old girl with two San Diego State teammates.
lead_paragraph: The Buffalo Bills cut Matt Araiza on Saturday, two days after the rookie punter was accused in a lawsuit of raping a 17-year-old girl last October with two of his teammates at San Diego State.
headline: Buffalo Bills Cut Matt Araiza Amid Rape Lawsuit
keywords: Araiza, Matt (2000- );Football;Sex Crimes;Suits and Litigation (Civil);Buffalo Bills;San Diego State University
